meta.title: KomPr3ssoR's DevLog
meta.subtitle: Some random logs of a self-study WebDev
meta.author: Xin Nie

posts.title: Operational Procedures
posts.text: Operational Procedures Documents You Need to KnowObjective 4.1 Compare and contrast best practices associated with types of documentation Objective term Network topology diagrams Logical diagram Physical diagram Acceptable use policy (AUP) Password policy Documents network assets through logical and physical diagrams Access good online sources for information, such as the Microsoft Knowledgebase Organizations follow rules for regulatory compliance Data You Need to KnowObjective 4.6 Explain the processes for addressing prohibited content/activity, and privacy, licensing, and policy concepts Objective term Personally identifiable information (PII) Protected health information (PHI) EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) Protect PII, such as social security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, etc Strict laws govern what organizations can do with PHI The GDPR in the EU specifies how and what data online organizations can get from visitors The payment card industry follows the PCI DDS to ensure security of financial interactions Change ManagementObjective 4.2 Given a scenario, implement basic change management best practices Objective term Change management Change board Documented business processes Purpose of the change Scope of the change Risk analysis Plan for change End-user acceptance Document changes Change management enables organizations to update systems safely and methodically Understand the change management process Change management follows clear steps, from the change board to enacting changes to documenting all changes The Zen of BackupObjective 4.3 Given a scenario, implement basic disaster prevention and recovery methods Objective term File-level backup Image-level backup Disaster recovery starts and ends with restorable backups File-level backups provide good protection for data Image-level backups enable full system recovery quickly Recycling and Data DestructionObjective 4.4 Explain common safety procedures Objective term Batteries Toner cartridges CRT Monitors Cell phones and tablets Low-level format Standard format Drive wipe/overwrite Degaussing machine Shredder Incineration Certificate of Destruction Take old computering parts, like toner cartridges and monitors, to recycling centers Reset all smartphones and tablets before reselling or donating Run drive-wiping software or physically destroy all mass media drive when disposing of them
posts.author: Xin Nie

posts.title: Securing Computers
posts.text: Securing Computers ThreatsObjective 2.5 Compare and contrast social engineering, threats, and vulnerabilities Objective term Man-in-the-Middle Spoofing Denial of Service (DoS) Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) Zero Day Renamed System Files Disappeared Files The term “security” encompasses host- and network-based security, and physical security Common threats include man-in-middle attacks, DoS, and DDoS attacks Symptoms of such attacks include renamed system files, missing files, and more. Physical SecurityObjective 2.1 Summarize the importance of physical security measures Physical security includes perimeter security, room locks, and individual device security Security guards and mantraps help perimeter security Locks, badges, smart cards, and biometrics enable room-level security Device security devices include server locks, USB locks, and screen filters Passwords and AuthenticationObjective 2.5 Given a scenario, implement security best practices to secure a workstation Modern password security relies on passwords and hashes Methods for cracking passwords and hashes include brute force, dictionary attacks,and rainbow tables Protect with best password practices, such as upper- and lower-case letters, numbers, and non-alphanumeric passwords; long passwords help, too MalwareObjective 2.4 Given a scenario, detect, remove and prevent malware using appropriate tools and methods Objective term Virus Worm Trojan horse Rootkit Ransomware Rogue Antivirus Botnet Keylogger Spyware Pop-ups Browser redirection Security alerts Application crashes OS Update failure Spam Hijacked e-mail Automated replies Invalid certificates (Trusted Root CA) Worms propagate via networking Trojan horses masquerade as benign programs, but carry a payload for later Ransomware attacks/locks down systems in exchange for money Malware infestations manifest as browser redirection, application crashes, update failures, and more Anti-MalwareObjective 3.3 Given a scenario, use best practice procedures for malware removal Objective term Anti-Malware Recovery console Backup/Restore End-user education Software firewalls Secure DNS CompTIA 7-Step Identify and research malware symptoms Quarantine the infected systems Disable System Restore (in Windows) Remediate the infected systems (a. Update the anti-malware softwares b. Scan and use removal techniques in safe mode, pre-installation environment) Schedule scans and run updates Enable System restore; also and create a restore point (in WIndows) Educate the end user Prepare for malware attacks with good backups, end-user education, and firewalls Use secure DNS options, such as a trusted third-party site and encryption Memorize the CompTIA A+ 7-step malware-recovery process Social EngineeringObjective 2.5 Compare and contrast social engineering, threats, and vulnerabilities Objective term Phishing Spear phishing Social engineering enables bad people to use information from people inside to gain access to sensitive information Social engineering attacks include telephone scams, tailgating, shoulder surfing, and dumpster diving Phishing and spear phishing attacks seek personal or financial information with targeted scams Social LicensingObjective 4.6 Explain the processes for addressing prohibited content/activity, and privacy, licensing, and policy concepts Objective term End-user license agreement (EULA) Digital rights management (DRM) GNU General Personal license (GNU GPL) Per-processor license for WIndows EULA describes what users can do with licensed software DRM controls what users can do with some content Producers retain all rights to commercial software Open-source software enables users to change or modify the software Incident ResponseObjective 4.6 Explain the processes for addressing prohibited content/activity, and privacy, licensing, and policy concepts Techs need to understand and implement proper incident response Know your responsibilities Identify the problem through reporting, preservation, and documentation Exercise proper chain-of-custody procedures Environmental ControlsObjective 4.5 Explain environmental impacts and appropriate controls Objective term Materials safety data sheet (MSDS) Temperature and humidity levels Proper ventilation Surge suppressor Dust and debris Enclosures Compressed air Anti-static vacuum Check the MSDS for any spills or problems with equipment Monitor temperature and humidity levels Ensure proper ventilation Employ surge suppressors and UPS backup devices Clean systems with compressed air and specialized vacuums
posts.author: Xin Nie

posts.title: Care and Feeding of Mobile Devices

posts.author: Xin Nie

posts.title: Portable Computing
posts.text: Portable Computing Power ManagementObjective 1.6 Given a scenario, use Microsoft Windows Control Panel utilities Objective term AC Adapter - Vendor-specific power ports ACPI - Advanced Configuration and Power Interface ACPI level 0 - Power is on ACPI level 3 - Sleep mode ACPI level 4 - Hibernation mode All OS provide power management utilities
posts.author: Xin Nie

posts.title: The Internet
posts.text: The Internet Objective 4.9 Given a scenario, use remote access technologies Telnet and SSH Objective Term: Telnet - Port 23 Secure Shell (SSH) - port 22 The Telnet and the Secure Shell (SSH) protocols provide command line access to remove systems Telnet runs on TCP port 23; SSH runs on TCP port 22 Telnet is unencrypted; SSH is encrypted Remote Desktop Connections Objective Term: Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) - Port 3389 Virtual Network Computing (VNC) - Port 5900+N Windows uses Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) for remote connectivity Use Virtual Network Computing (VNC) protocol for connecting to Linux and Mac systems Try Tight VNC to use VNC from a Windows system The World Wide WebObjective 2.2 Explain logical security concepts Objective Term: HTTP - port 80 (insecure) HTTPS - port 443 (encrypts everything) Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) Transport Layer Security (TLS) The World Wide Web uses either the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) or HTTP Secure (HTTPS) protocols HTTP uses port 80 and is not secure HTTPS uses port 443 and uses certificates to make a secure connection Make sure to recognize typical certificate errors Troubleshooting Internet ConnectionsObjective 1.4 Given a scenario, use appropriate Microsoft command line tools Check your physical system first Know your network ipconfig/all Know your network connectivity tracert(Win), traceroute(Linux/Mac) ping
posts.author: Xin Nie

posts.title: Wireless Networking
posts.text: Wireless Networking Objective 2.3 Compare and contrast wireless security protocols and authentication methods Wireless Encryption Objective Term: WEP (Wired Equivalent Privacy) TKIP (Temporal Key Integrity Protocol) AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) WPA (Wi-Fi Protected Access) WPS (Wi-Fi Protected Setup) The obsolete WEP encryption is easily cracked today and is never used WPA introduced TKIP-personal shared key and RADIUS authentication WPA2 added AES encryption WPS automates encryption, but is easily crackable Enterprise Wireless Object Term: Power over Ethernet (PoE) PoE (1st generation) and PoE+ PoE injector AAA - authorization, authentication, accounting RADIUS or TACACS+ Extended SSID (ESSID) Enterprise WAPs often use Power over Ethernet (PoE) Use powerful wireless analysis tools to determine WAP location Enterprise networks often use RADIUS or TACACS+ protocols for authentication Two or more WAPs sharing the same SSID are known as ESSIDs
posts.author: Xin Nie

posts.title: Port Forwarding
posts.text: Port Forwarding A port forward is when a NAT router opens incoming traffic on a certain port access to a single system on the internal network You configure port forwarding on the NAT router We often use nonstandard port numbers for security reasons We use Dynamic DNS to give DNS names to port forwarded devices
posts.author: Xin Nie

posts.title: Windows Firewall
posts.text: Windows Firewall Host Firewall Host firewall is an individual firewall. Windows Defender Firewall is a host-based firewall that comes with Windows Host firewalls protect systems using host features such as file names or process IDs Windows defender firewall has three settings: Domain network Private network Guest or public network Network discovery & exception You can create exceptions manually if needed
posts.author: Xin Nie

posts.title: Hello World
posts.text: Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub. Quick StartCreate a new post1$ hexo new "My New Post" More info: Writing Run server1$ hexo server More info: Server Generate static files1$ hexo generate More info: Generating Deploy to remote sites1$ hexo deploy More info: Deployment
